In the video's scenario, that is not why the string snaps. You need to include the perspective of both rockets and the outside observer. Basically the string will snap because the rockets will accelerate faster than the signal along the string can propagate to the behind rocket. In your model, you keep showing the string as more of a static object, but in real life, the string will not stay tense. Like from the rear rocket's perspective, the string will begin to bundle up, and will only break because the lead rocket brings the string past it's tensile strength. Without adding real numbers, it is hard to determine if the string will break or be fine, as it heavily determines on how fast the rocket's accelerate, how long the string is, what the tension strength of the string is, what the propagation speed of the string is, what the mass of the string is, and when each rocket leaves (like an agreed upon time or when the lead rocket observes the rear rocket moving).

Consider this other scenario. The lead rocket accelerates, and has a light-year long string trailing behind it (No rear rocket), assuming the acceleration is slow enough and the string is strong enough to hold itself together, then in the scenarios where both rockets leave at an agreed upon time (which is what I'm assuming this video is assuming), the string will also be able to hold itself together. As the rear rocket will actually be pushing the string closer to the lead rocket by the time the signal of the lead rocket leaving reaches the rear rocket.

In the video, you don't even need to add a rear rocket, because the assumptions made would make a trailing string behind the rocket also break. Give the string a real mass, propagation speed, tension strength, and give the rocket a constant acceleration, and you will see that if you make sure the string doesn't break, it will not break in any scenario.

So if you calculate the original video scenario all out, what an outside observer will see will be very similar to what the behind rocket will see. It is essentially the rear rocket catching up to the rocket infront of it and the string beginning to bundle up and drag behind the rear rocket, where it gets interesting is the lead rocket which will "see" the string stretch out and become longer, but this effect will be counteracted by the contraction of space between the rockets and the string will actually remain the same size.

Also worth noting, something that failed to include in the calculation is that the front rocket and rear rocket (if leaving at an agreed upon time) will actually see length contraction of the space between the rockets, as each rocket will observe the other one moving at different speed due to the finite speed of light.

Also worth noting, that if the string is so tense that it will not stretch at all, it will break at the point where it attaches to the lead rocket, as stretching is how objects accelerate as a "single" object.

By the way, I came to all this by trying to find a scenario where the string does not break and stays tense, and if you calculate it out, it occurs if the rear rocket matches the observed speed of string (and if the string propagates at the speed of light, then it would be the observed speed of the lead rocket), this will create not tension on the string and will be very similar to the scenario of the lead rocket dragging a string behind it. There are two problems here. One is that inertial reference frames are distinctly different from accelerating reference frames, and the video is sloppy about it, only comparing inertial frames at different times. The other is that the video confuses relativistic phenomena such as length contraction with real physical forces such as string tension: length contraction is uniform, but string tension is not. Whether the string breaks depends on how resilient the string is, and has nothing to do with acceleration or length contraction per se.

Consider the case of the OBSERVER accelerating, with the rockets turned off in an inertial frame. The observer will see the rockets and string getting shorter and shorter over time. The string doesn't break, because there are no forces on the rockets or the string: no engines have been turned on.

In the case of the rockets accelerating instead of the observer (the case in this video), one has to be VERY careful about what one means as "simultaneous". It would be accurate to say that in any real physical situation, there is no such thing as simultaneous. One rocket will start sooner than the other (and thus they will either move closer or further apart, all else being equal). If we idealize the situation and assume that the rockets both start simultaneously as measured in their INITIAL REST FRAME, e.g., via synchronized clocks, then they will remain a constant distance from each other as measured in their (now accelerating) frame. Neither spacecraft sees the other shrink, nor do they observe the string to contract along its length.

The principle of equivalence applies in this idealized case: just as the rockets and string would all fall at the same rate in a uniform gravitational field, they should all accelerate at the same rate in our idealized simultaneous case. Except the acceleration from a pair of rockets is NOT as uniform as a gravitational field.

Where the video gets confused is mixing up the relativistic phenomenon of "length contraction" with the VERY different phenomenon that acceleration is typically not uniform: bodies are pushed by real physical forces in a non-uniform way. The rocket engine pushes on the rear of the spacecraft, which in turn pushes gradually on the middle and front of the spacecraft. In the case of the string, the rear spacecraft cannot push the string, so the string starts collecting on the front of the spacecraft. The front spacecraft pulls on the string, but the string reacts sort of like a rubber band or slinky, with the lead end of the string getting stretched out (which may or may not be forceful enough to break the string), and the middle and rear parts of the string slowly catching up. All strings work like this, more or less, even the strongest and most resilient: it's just that a very strong cord doesn't stretch as much and transmits its tension faster than a rubber band or slinky.

Adding this concept to the very idealized case, what we would have is the string stretching out and wobbling a bit as the acceleration is introduced into the system. A very high acceleration would rip the string apart instantly - never mind crushing the ships. A very low acceleration wouldn't break the string at all, and all the materials would reach an equilibrium being accelerated at about the same rate.

In other words, there is NO observable perspective in which the string breaks due to "length contraction". Length contraction is not a physical entity, just as relativistic mass isn't really mass (different discussion, but worth googling if you're interested). There is a real issue with respect to forces being limited to propagating at the speed of light (if not even more slowly - e.g., the speed of "sound" through the string), and those forces could cause the string to break. But those forces arise from the mechanics of how the system is accelerating, not from any sort of relativistic effect such as length contraction. Again, using the principle of equivalence, if the entire system were accelerated in a uniform gravitational field, all parts of the system would experience no acceleration or forces at all, and nothing would be pulling or pushing or breaking.

First, no, the rockets are not independent objects at all. Nor is the string a separate thing from them. That isn't how reality works to our best level of understanding. Everything is quantum (sorry Copenhagenists). So either there is no distinction between objects or frames of reference at all, and SR is wrong... or every point in spacetime is its own distinct object, and all deformations due to special or general relativity are smooth and continuous, and the relativistic effects are applied smoothly and continuously both between and within each body in question, and SR is correct (but misapplied here).

Thus, all objects should experience internal stresses, due to length contraction and/or non-simultaneity as they accelerate. However, these forces should be absolutely miniscule to the point of being effectively undetectable, compared to the more ordinary, inertial forces involved in that level of acceleration. The reason they don't pull apart due to the length contraction/non-simultaneity is because the chemical bonds between the atoms are strong enough to withstand those forces.

This I see three basic regimes for a string/cable stretched between the two rockets (assuming spherical cows etc; in reality the string would probably break almost all the time long before relativistic effects become relevant, just due to random thermal fluctuations in the combustion chambers/nozzles).

1. The acceleration is fast enough that, despite being flawlessly simultaneous, the string snaps because the string itself can't bear the force of its own acceleration, i.e. mundane inertial forces break the strong.

2. The acceleration is slow and gentle enough that the relativistic forces between the rockets are within the tensile strength limit of the string. In this case, just like the rockets don't tear themselves apart, they don't tear the string apart either.

3. Possibly in some very narrow regime between the two, there might be a tiny sliver of a regime in which the kinetic/inertial forces aren't quite strong enough to shred the string, but the acceleration is just ever so slightly too fast for the string to provide sufficient force to simply pull the rockets closer together rather than breaking. Consider that, while weak, the string is still capable of handling many many many many more orders of magnitude more force than the gravity between the rockets. Both are way, way smaller than the forces involved in the acceleration, but the string is still able to do more than your intuition suggests.

I strongly suspect that for the vast majority of materials the string/cable could be made out of, that third regime doesn't actually exist. Actually, I suspect, with not quite as much certainty that the overlap between regimes 1 and 2 is quite vast, and that regime 3 is completely impossible.
